Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Balancing selection and MHC variation in an endangered bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
A major question in conservation biology is why some populations with low levels of genetic variation remain relatively stable while others decline in size. Stable populations may not have lost genetic variation related to disease resistance, such as the suite of resistance genes known as the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). Theory suggests that natural selection is more likely to maintain functionally important MHC variation in populations that have experienced declines in size. This study will make direct estimates of natural selection on the MHC and other immunity genes using data from both historic and contemporary populations of the greater prairie-chicken, which is one of the most threatened species of bird in North America. This project will also examine the association between variation at MHC genes and parasites, immunity and survival in two small populations that are undergoing augmentation with translocations (Wisconsin) and captive breeding (Texas) to increase genetic variation.

The results of this study will be valuable for biologists studying the effects of population size on disease and parasite resistance, and it will provide management guidelines for captive breeding and translocating animals, practices that are likely to increase with continuing loss of prairie habitat. Graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher will be trained in immunogenetics, and the project should lead to valuable new genetic markers for studying immunity-related genes in other species. The PIs will work with environmental education centers in Milwaukee and Dallas-Fort Worth on citizen science and teacher education projects that focus on the health of wildlife. The results will be broadly disseminated to state and federal wildlife agencies, environmental groups and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is increasing concern that outbreaks of emerging pathogens may increase the risk of extinction in wildlife populations.  For example, West Nile Virus appears to cause 100% mortality in sage-grouse.  In this study we examined the diversity of immune genes in another grouse species, the greater prairie-chicken, which also has small, endangered populations. Genetic variation at immune genes is related to the ability to resist pathogens, and, thus, may be important for the survival of populations. We studied the causes of variation in immune genes and their relationship to population size, immune responses and survival in the wild. As part of a collaboration with the Wisconsin Dept. of Natural Resources (WDNR), we also examined how genetic variation (in immune and other genes) is changed by translocations of prairie-chickens, a practice that is increasingly used by natural resource agencies.

Greater prairie-chicken populations occur in fragmented populations throughout the midwest that differ dramatically in size (100 to >150,000 birds) and isolation. Our study populations have declined an average of 57% in population size since historic (<1954) times, and this is associated with an average 14% decline in neutral genetic variation.  As in many other studies, we that found immune genetic variation was lower in small populations due to the random loss of genes that occurs when there are few individuals in a population (ie, genetic drift). However, we were surprised to find that as population size decreased, variation at immune genes was lost at a faster rate than non-functional (neutral) genes.  This result was surprising because it has been suggested that selection would maintain immune gene variation, which is important for disease resistance. Computer simulations showed that the higher rate of loss at immune genes could be explained partly by random loss of individuals with multiple copies of those immune genes. In other words, some individuals are carriers of more immune gene variation than others, and just by chance when these individuals die or fail to breed they cause a greater loss of variation at immune than neutral genes. 

We also helped to design and implement a translocation of birds from Minnesota to Wisconsin to restore genetic variation. The Wisconsin population of prairie-chickens has declined from 2,000 birds in the early 1950's to less than 300 birds, and as a consequence, the population has lost genetic variation that may be important for surviving new diseases and other environmental changes. To help restore some of the lost genetic variation, we participated in a translocation of 110 females from Minnesota, which has greater genetic diversity, to Wisconsin.  Two years after the last translocation, we found that there was an increase in genetic diversity at one particular neutral gene, but not at several others that have different functions and types of inheritance. These results caution against interpreting the success of translocations based on a single type of genetic marker, and they also illustrate that the success of restoration projects may depend on how the genetic goals are defined. We continue to monitor genetic variation in the Wisconsin population in collaboration with the WDNR.  We are also in the final stages of preparing publications on immune gene variation across the entire range of prairie-chickens, as well as other species of grouse in the midwest.

We have developed and shown the utility of a variety of immune gene markers in prairie-chickens.  These markers provide a toolkit for other researchers to continue studying the ecology of disease resistance in wild bird populations.
